body:
In addition, being able to set the blur level would be great as well, similar to Terminal.

![screen shot 2014-06-05 at 9 48 23 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/82437/3188151/19c8e652-ecb8-11e3-86e1-1932c9823692.png)

``` javascript
app.commandLine.appendSwitch('enable-transparent-visuals'); // try add this line
```

Is there a way to support fully transparent browser windows?

The window basecolor seams to be white now, sure we can style it with css color but not set it to transparent. 

Something like this:
https://github.com/rogerwang/node-webkit/issues/132
+1 We do need that!

I tried to implement transparency but I did not succeed; still my code might serve as inspiration for someone else: https://github.com/sauerbraten-fork/sauerbraten-fork-atom-ui

There also seems to be a thread about chromium supporting transparency, but I don't think they did anything for OS X/win/GTK: https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=260810
FWIW, some older Chrome themes used transparency, but I was told by a Chromium dev that this was finally rubbed out.
What's the crack with this then? Will we be able to support transparency in atom shell?

As far as I remember [Tint](https://github.com/trueinteractions/tint2) had cross-platform transparency
[TIWindow.create](https://www.trueinteractions.com/docs/TIWindow.html#create) (glass option)
I seriously doubt this will be possible ever, since it's based on Chromium and Chromium has decided to not support transparency.

This works on node-webkit under https://github.com/rogerwang/node-webkit/pull/2463. (Confirmed by these binaries: https://github.com/jtg-gg/node-webkit/releases/tag/nw-v0.10.2-transparency)

I haven't had time to dig into the atom-shell implementation of webkit, but I wonder if we can get this to work on atom-shell as well? I would be happy to give this a shot, so if someone has an idea of where to start, please let me know!
This is awesome news. Hopefully this can make it into atom-shell soon?
This would be great, I miss this from TM1. I've been using sublime long enough that I'm used to not having it anymore, but it would be great to get it back.
We definitely need this for what we're working on at Slack, I might start to work on try getting in these patches to libchromiumcontent to start
@paulcbetts Sounds exciting! Looking forward to seeing what you guys are up to. :heart_eyes:
@paulcbetts When do you think you could have something working?
@iamdriz Hell if I know
+1 would love this feature!
+1 It is needed definitely!

For me the biggest problem is the maintenance of libchromiumcontent patches, to support window transparency we have to patch some very deep portions of Chromium code, which means for each release of Chrome I have to revisit those patches and test whether it works on every platform, which will be a great burden.

But having so many requests on this I now think I'm :+1: on this.

@zcbenz The patches are actually not tooooooo bad, I've got most of them moved over against our current Chrome 39: https://gist.github.com/paulcbetts/e02e11bf299a2124ef0f (WIP, not finished, prob. doesn't even compile). I think that most of the code that this touches is fairly stable, so there isn't much reason to change it

I'm working on a painting program that I've moved from node-webkit because performance in atom-shell is much faster, and one of the things I really want to do is trace over other areas of my screen like this: (screenshot from node-webkit build)
![screenshot 2014-12-11 08 18 56](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3620017/5512133/ecf5b8de-87a4-11e4-916c-77292b05efde.png)

No other drawing software really has full transparency like this and I'm super excited to make something that does. Anyway... would be very grateful if this could make it in :).
That's nice, hope this feature would be landing down as fast as possible.
So thats means Atom have support for it too ? or atom haven't swtich to that version>?
ï¼‹1,it is great
thats sooo awesome @zcbenz  , so awesome that it give me tears! Soon we can have transulant atoms running :D .
+1 great on OS X 10.11

Any progress on blurred background like https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/381#issuecomment-45220895? +1 for that
Ref NW.js again https://github.com/nwjs/nw.js/issues/132
+1 I'm glad the first part works but the blur really would be nice.

Untested by from [here](http://lurk.org/groups/tidal/messages/topic/18D8UrgeQxqsReDL3Kv0Wx):

> Thought I would share this in case it's useful. I figured out how to make the
> Atom editor transparent, mostly gleaned from various forums around the web,
> gathered here for future reference.
> 
> Can't attach this gif from some reason, but my set-up now looks like this:
> https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/2177570/transparentAtom.gif
> 
> (I have only tested this on a Mac running El Capitan).
> 1. Download the Atom repository from github (https://github.com/atom/atom)
> 2. Open up this file: ~/atom/src/browser/atom-window.coffee
> 3. At line 26, change this:
>    
>    options =
>      show: false
>      title: 'Atom'
>      'web-preferences':
>        'direct-write': true
> 
> to this:
> 
> ```
> options =
>   frame: true
>   transparent: true
>   title: 'Atom'
>   'web-preferences':
>     'direct-write': true
>     'subpixel-font-scaling': true
> ```
> 
> (it could be that you literally just need the 'transparent:true' command here
> and that those other extras are superfluous, but I haven't recompiled Atom to
> find out).
> 1. Compile this version of Atom (this is always a bit trial and error for me. I
>    suspect most people here know how to do it in their sleep. I navigated to the
>    atom directory in terminal and ran this: script/build --install-dir ~/<path to
>    wherever>/Atom.app
> 2. In Atom, go to Packages > Package Generator > Generate Atom Syntax Theme and
>    name a new theme
> 3. Go to Preferences > Themes. Find your theme, select it, and then choose
>    'view code'
> 4. This should open a branch of all the files for the new syntax you've
>    created. Find your base.less style sheet and tailor it to suit your needs. More
>    info on theme customisation here (https://atom.io/docs/v1.2.0/)
> 
> I kept it super simple just using these lines which just turn the alpha channel
> of the background right now.
> 
> html, body, atom-workspace, atom-pane-container atom-pane {
>   background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0) !important;
>   }
> 
> atom-text-editor, :host {
>   background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1);
>   color: @syntax-text-color;
> 
> You can quickly check changes (on a mac anyways) by saving the file and hitting
> ctrl-alt-cmd-l to reload Atom.
> 
> If this works for you, it's also worth having a 2nd version of Atom handy which
> doesn't have transparency enabled, cos it can get annoying if you're not in
> performance mode and just wanna do some coding.
> 
> For the record, this was the original post that got me started
> (https://www.reddit.com/r/Atom/comments/33u7ec/transparent_window_test/)
> 
> It's working pretty well for me. Means I can run an OSC-receiving app I've made
> in Unity behind the code. Hopefully in the future will contribute a unity
> package. Right now it's a bit too scrappy/customised to very specific needs.
> Ought to make it a bit more open-ended/flexible before it's worth sharing.>
@afang I was just looking for this too. If I am not mistaken, by now transparent window-backgrounds are possible, but blurred translucent backgrounds (as in OS X Yosemite) aren't.

@afang It seems like it is also [an open issue in nw.js](https://github.com/nwjs/nw.js/issues/2817).

Also [I found this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YvMaVSSI2v4), apparently a demo to a bug report for electron _using a blurred background_, but I cannot find the original issue.

One last comment before I spam this issue too much: I talked to the guy of the video I linked to in my previous post: What he did was to blur and reposition an image to fake a blurred translucent background, so no fix there.
@afang I believe this is not the place to discuss these questions.
@LukasBombach is it implemented with electron in that video? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YvMaVSSI2v4
Yes, that is electron, but apparently it's a big hack that does not really work, you can find the guy on twitter for questions: [@FirePanther](https://twitter.com/FirePanther)
Buggy to me too... strange shadows and blinking rects.
+1 here. Really helps bridge the "is this a real Mac app?" feeling.
I agree with @maxvoltar . Big :+1:
Does anybody have strange shadow bugs?
I also have strange shadow bugs too and animations are really laggy. Everything seems fine when I oven the DevTools, though.
@T-Specht same issue here.
https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/4157

@T-Specht @fyodorvi Launching Atom with these parameters fixes the shadow bugs for me.

```
--enable-transparent-visuals --disable-gpu
```

I think it's the fact that Atom's using `translate3d` in the CSS, and it's causing the shadow  issues. Finally I can switch to Atom at this point with the transparency working.
@garand @T-Specht @fyodorvi @jiyinyiyong @LukasBombach Here's a working port for OS X https://github.com/sgarbesi/atom

ðŸ‘  Great !
However, did you notice sluggish performance by deactivating gpu - and can it still be activated on single elements within the UI ?
@mentalgear I didn't, but I'm on a quad core laptop with 16gb of memory.

Is it able to detect if `transparent` would work on this machine?
In Windows, it seems that if the user didn't turn on `visual styles`, transparent would not work.
In nwjs, I do it by checking `win.isTransparent`. https://github.com/nwjs/nw.js/wiki/Window#windowistransparent
Help, thanks!
Very much interested in this as well!
Guys, what if Chromium has dropped transparency? Isn't it open source? Can't we make a patch or something? ;P
